awd_titl_txt: RUI: Dicarboximide-functionalized Oxanorbornyl Homopolymers and Diblock Copolymers for Use as Solid Polymer Electrolytes
awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

Energy storage devices, such as lithium-ion batteries, are an increasingly important technology to most areas of society due to their broad use in devices from electronics and power tools to automobiles. As news reports have noted, improved safety and performance of such batteries are vital as their use grows. This research project will develop and study new polymer materials for use as membranes in lithium-ion batteries. These polymers might allow batteries to be constructed out of materials that are much less flammable than current ones, and to be lighter, flexible, or have more storage. This work will also include collaborations with scientists at other institutions and national facilities such as Argonne National Laboratory. Benefits to the future scientific workforce include undergraduate student involvement in all aspects of this research at a predominantly undergraduate institution. Outreach activities will be undertaken with underrepresented high school students through involvement with the Mathematics, Engineering, and Science Achievement (MESA) program. 



TECHNICAL SUMMARY:

New polymers will be developed for potential use as solid polymer electrolyte supports in lithium-ion or other next-generation batteries. The major objective of this research is to better understand how to design polymers to facilitate the decoupling of ion motion from local segmental motion. These polymers will be based on dicarboximide oxanorbornene monomers. Homopolymers and diblock copolymers will be synthesized using ring-opening metathesis polymerization. The homopolymers studied will focus on structures that have high salt solubility and an increased fragility parameter as well as structures that incorporate the salt as part of the monomer itself. The former will be studied as a function of molecular weight and with structural changes to increase the fragility parameter. The diblock copolymers will incorporate the ion conducting monomer in one block and a high modulus monomer in the other block. The diblock copolymer morphologies should allow the blending of these two properties on a nanometer lengthscale. These new materials will be evaluated by dielectric spectroscopy, atomic force microscopy, DSC, and potentially solid-state NMR. If scattering data (X-rays or neutrons) are needed, this research will be conducted with collaborators or at national laboratories. Undergraduate student researchers will be involved in all aspects of this research.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The work undertaken in this Research in Undergraduate Institutions (RUI) award synthesized and studied tailored polymer materials for use in lithium-ion batteries with a goal of improved safety and efficacy. These new materials might contribute to lithium batteries being lighter, smaller, and be constructed out of materials that are much less flammable than conventional materials. Batteries that would use materials like this are often referred to as solid state lithium-ion batteries where the electrolyte could be a solid polymer hosting a lithium salt. One central challenge of this research was improving the motion of lithium ions in polymer materials. To do this, we designed and synthesized polymers that tried to separate the molecular motion of the polymer from the motion of the ions. The primary outcomes related to intellectual merit are summarized here: 

  • We successfully synthesized polymers with a bulky backbone and short segments of ethylene oxide as sidechains.
  • We measured the rate of motion in these materials at different temperatures.
  • We succeeded in reaching our goal of ion motion albeit at 70 to 80 degrees C. 
  • The new polymer materials didn't crystalize at room temperature.
  • The new materials were also incorporated in block copolymers where one component contributed to ion motion and the second component contributed material strength.
  • The block copolymers were studied using X-ray scattering and a few types of atomic force microscopy.
  • Lastly, we made significant progress developing a new polymer material that should allow only the lithium ion to have motion while restricting the motion of the counter ion. This should also help improve the motion of the lithium ions.

This work resulted in eleven presentations by undergraduate students and the principal investigator in a variety of local, national, and international venues. It also resulted in two publications with undergraduate co-authors:

  • Noncontact Imaging of Ion Dynamics in Polymer Electrolytes with Time-Resolved Electrostatic Force Microscopy (doi:10.1021/acsnano.8b07254)
  • Characterization of morphology in ring-opening metathesis polymerized novel solid block copolymer electrolytes by atomic force microscopy and X-ray scattering (doi:10.1016/j.electacta.2018.12.051)

This award included a number of broader impacts. Our nation's future scientific work force was impacted through the training and education of eleven undergraduate students in all aspects of this award's research. Of the ten students who have graduated, five are now in graduate school, one is in the medical school, two are in secondary education, and two are in the work force. Collaborations were established with scientists other local and national universities. Outreach activities were undertaken with underrepresented junior high and high school students involving the local Mathematics, Engineering, and Science Achievement (MESA) program in all of the summers except when the pandemic precluded in-person gatherings. These activities included undergraduate research students providing polymer science experiential learning activities, chemical demonstrations, and demonstrations of modern scientific instrumentation.


Last Modified: 09/26/2021
Modified by: Dean A Waldow

To do this, we designed and synthesized polymers that tried to separate the molecular motion of the polymer from the motion of the ions. We measured the rate of motion in these materials at different temperatures.
